search_result.title: 13 gang members face 91 charges, including murder
search_result.text:
Brittany Horn

The News Journal

WILMINGTON City and state officials announced Friday the indictment of 13 "Touch Money Gang" members on 91 charges including murder, robbery, conspiracy and weapons charges.

All 13 are now in custody following a monthslong investigation into gang activity, state Attorney General Matt Denn said. Members of the gang who were arrested range in age from 15-23.

This is considered the "largest indictment in memory" by the Department of Justice in terms of the number of homicides and shootings involved in the charges.

The crimes include six slayings, five shootings with injuries and a bank robbery.

"The level of violence and brazenness alleged to have been exhibited by TMG members is shocking," Denn said. "The number of shots being fired and the indiscriminate nature of the shootings are alarming."

The youngest alleged gang member, Raymire Briscoe, was 14 when he killed Dwayne Brown in the area of 10th and Kirkwood streets on May 8, 2014, according to court documents. Tymere Righter, 19, also was charged in connection with Brown's slaying.

"We want to send a message. ... There is no fame or glory to be had in using a gun," Denn said.

Family members of the gun violence were also in attendance and thanked law enforcement officials for their hard work in bringing their loved ones' killers to justice.

But no amount of closure will bring back their children, said Shareece White, whose 18-year-old son William Rollins was gunned down on Wilmington's streets.

Rollins was shot and killed at the corner of West 21st and Washington streets on Jan. 24.

"They didn't shoot my baby one time," she said through tears. "They shot him multiple times."

John Brisco, 18 – also known as "Bin Laden" – was charged with Rollins' death, as well as the murder of two other Wilmington men since 2013. He faces 21 charges, including murder, possession of a firearm, attempted robbery, among others, according to court documents.

Kadir McCoy, 17 – also known as "D-Rose" – also was charged with the murder of Rollins. He faces additional charges in relation to a slaying that occurred just days before that of Rollins, as well as robbery charges involving a WSFS Bank branch, carrying a concealed deadly weapon and others, according to court documents.

Rollins' mother pleaded with the community to come forward and speak up about what they see and hear in the streets – something Denn cited as key to making these arrests possible.

"It's not snitching," White said pausing. "Save your own life. Because if you know something and they find out, they're coming for you next."

Wilmington homicide arrest rate triples

Growing up between the bullets in Wilmington

Wilmington Police Chief Bobby Cummings said Friday's arrests also pushed the city's homicide closure rate to 52 percent for 2015.

Just last week, Cummings cited a 37 percent clearance rate for homicides this year — three times as many compared with 12 percent in 2014.

Ten of the 20 shooting homicides in the city this year have been closed with an arrest, Cummings said Friday.

The following individuals were indicted on 91 charges: John Brisco, 18; Raymire Briscoe, 15; Alexander Fitzgerald, 19; Bryant Hawkes, 20; Aquantay Garner, 19; Rylier Grayson, 20; Ronald Maddrey, 20; Kadir McCoy, 17; Tymere Righter, 19; Jacquez Robinson, 20; Randy Scott, 23; Jaymere White, 17; and Daymere Wisher, 16.

The indictment is thick and details criminal activity and gang participation from Jan. 1, 2013, to Aug. 26, 2015. Officials cite 45 different occasions during which gang members intimidated or engaged others in participating with the Touch Money Gang.

Of those arrested, the following also were charged in unsolved murders from 2013 to 2015:

• Brisco and Wisher – aka "Day-Day" – were charged with the murder of Ioannis Kostikidis, a security guard at the American Beauty School who was shot and killed during a robbery attempt at Sixth and Tatnall streets on Feb. 6 2013.

• Brisco also was charged with the murder of 20-year-old Devon Lindsey, who was shot and killed on East 29th Street on Jan. 18.

• Robinson, 20 – also known as "Quez" – was previously indicted in the murder of Malik Watson, who was killed on Ninth Street in New Castle on Nov. 26, 2014. Friday's announcement linked him to the gang activity, according to the indictment.

The city has seen 89 shootings this year, with 100 people hit. So far, the city is on par for killings compared with September 2014, but more shootings have occurred and more people have been injured in the crossfire.

Families of those killed say their children were on their way to making changes and turning their lives around. Deshon Sellers had yet to celebrate his 18th birthday when he was shot and killed on East 24th Street near Carter Street on Feb. 16.

His mother, Lanita Brooks, said their family celebrated his twin sister's birthday this year but did so without their brother.

"In my 37 years, I've never experienced pain like that," she said.

Her son left the house and within five minutes was fatally shot up the street, she said.

Fitzgerald, 19, was charged with murdering Sellers, according to the indictment.

"I knew my son wasn't going to make it," Brooks said through tears. "He couldn't respond to me when I was there. ... I just want to say thank you to all of you all who worked on this case because without you this wouldn't be possible."

City officials recently credited the police department's involvement as one of five cities in the new federal Violence Reduction Network for helping raise the homicide arrest rate.

The network has provided additional resources, such as city police access to experienced federal government officials, collaboration with the state Office of the Attorney General to facilitate homicide arrests, as well as training for detective division officers in areas including homicide protocol, case management and crime-solving strategy.

And the intensity of officers out on the street will be changing, Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams said Friday. As recently as last week, Williams said he advised the chief to to increase aggressive patrols and move people off street corners more often.

"Criminals stick together; law enforcement must stick together," he said. "We have to stop looking at overtime dollars and things of that nature when people go out and commit heinous crimes and murder people. Life should not have a price on it."

But his resounding mantra, repeated numerous times Friday, was simple: Those coming to Wilmington to commit deadly crimes will be caught, one way or another.

"You come to Wilmington with a gun," he said, "you're done."

search_result.title: Dozens of arrests do little to stop Wilmington's cycle of gang violence
search_result.text:
Jordan Ellerbe was the first teen gunned down in a killing that state prosecutors say catalyzed a rivalry between two Wilmington street gangs.

He wasn't the last to die.

Next was Ryan Schneese. Then Brandon Wingo.

Then Tyreek Scott.

Kaden Young.

Yaseem Powell.

David Bailey.

And, most recently, Jeremy Tunnell.

More were injured in the warring gunfire that spiked after Ellerbe’s death three years ago: Isaiah Lecompte, Elijah Thomas, Zaire Dollard, and Zamyr Garcia, who remains paralyzed from the neck down.

Based on the shootings and the accompanying indictments against the Only My Brothers and Shoot to Kill gangs, there are likely more. And dozens of young men have been charged by state prosecutors in sweeping indictments.

Behind all the violence, rap songs from Wilmington's underground music scene tell the narrative of a gang feud yet to be settled.

"This one for my brothers," a teen who goes by the name "JordanWorldStoner" raps in honor of Ellerbe, who was never charged with a crime and was not the target of the shooting that killed him. "I know that we gon’ ride and we gon’ kill for each other."

Charges keep coming

Jeremy Tunnell, a teen from West Center City, spent the last years of his life in and out of prison.

Early last year, the 19-year-old pleaded guilty to a felony charge for being a member of the Only My Brothers gang. He also pleaded to weapons and other charges as part of the initial OMB indictment.

In May, a judge granted a recommendation that gainful employment replace a diploma requirement as part of his probation.

He was dead two weeks later, shot just blocks from his home. His killer remains at large.

"You don't graduate from gangster. You don't retire from gangster," Wilmington Rev. Derrick Johnson told teens as he preached at the recent funeral of another teenager shot to death. "You die or live the rest of your life in jail."

A year ago, The News Journal documented how those age 12 to 17 are more likely to be shot in Wilmington than any other U.S. city, and how prosecutors believe the STK and OMB rivalry is responsible for much of that violence.

GROWING UP UNDER FIRE

Wilmington: most dangerous place in America for youth

Wilmington suspects get younger, but their guns are more powerful

Young men charged as gang members rap about shootings, guns in music videos

Since that September 2017 story, more than three dozen people 20 and younger have been shot in Wilmington. Nine of those have been fatal, and most, like Tunnell's murder, are unsolved.

Police do not report the names of victims of non-fatal shootings so it is unclear how many of those might be related to the STK and OMB rivalry. One indicted Shoot to Kill member was injured in a February shooting. Garcia, paralyzed from the neck down, was shot earlier this year.

But court documents and social media posts show that many young men continue to fall victim to this deadly rivalry.

This summer, prosecutors have indicted 17 accused OMB and STK members, primarily teens, on charges of felony gang participation.

All of those indicted for gang participation with OMB have previously been charged with such affiliation. The STK indictment adds new defendants to the gang's loosely defined membership.

Previous gang indictments included other heavy charges such as armed robbery and murder. The current round appears to be based largely on the defendants possessing guns and appearing together in music videos posted online as well as social media posts.

“Under our current gang statute, even an Instagram post can be construed as promoting criminal activity by other members of the group," said Patrick Collins, an attorney representing two teens indicted in the most recent gang charges.

The Delaware Department of Justice declined to make prosecutors available for an interview on the indictment, and the full scope of the evidence against the defendants is unclear.

"Our prosecutors, working closely with law enforcement, have identified criminal street gangs as drivers of much of the violence in the city over the past several years," DOJ Spokesman Carl Kanefsky said in an email. "Where the evidence supports criminal connections and multiple acts of violence, we bring gang prosecutions."

The names keep popping up

Online posts have been key to prosecutors establishing the existence of the OMB and STK gangs and their rivalry.

The groups are not like a traditional gang with a defined power structure and tangible goal such as drug sales. Prosecutors have described STK and OMB as bands of friends passing insults online and committing violence offline.

Earlier this year, prosecutors used social media posts referencing gang slang and previous shootings as part of its successful effort to convince a jury that the murder of 15-year-old Brandon Wingo in 2016 was gang related.

At least part of the current indictment of STK members involves a music video depicting several accused gang members together.

In the videos, they rap openly about the violence, paying tribute to Jordan Ellerbe and Ryan Schneese. Young men from the Only My Brothers gang are believed to have carried out these shootings.

One YouTube video is listed in court records as evidence against those indicted as part of the Shoot To Kill gang. The video, titled “Bounce Out With That,'' is by the artist “Cbandz,” whose real name is Chaz T. Cowan, a 18-year-old charged as a member of STK.

The full video appears to have been removed from YouTube, but a 30-second clip is still available on Facebook. In it are references to “Jordan World,” shootings, robberies and drugs.

"Don't talk just shoot when we see the opps," Cowan states in the song. Police interpret the word "opps" to mean opposing gang members.

Another video posted online, titled “Letting Go” by the artist who calls himself “JordanWorldStoner,” features multiple young men who have been charged as members of the Shoot to Kill gang. The song itself talks about what these young men are willing to do for each other.

"I know that we gon’ slide and do drills for each other,” raps JordanWorldStoner. Prosecutors have reasoned in court that drills reference shooting.

Part of the video is shot at the gravesite of David Bailey, who was killed last year in a Wilmington shooting. Police charged 17-year-old Aaron L. Miles with the murder of Bailey, whose cut-out appears in the music video.

Bailey’s mother, Tonya, said her son and Ellerbe knew each other through their groups of friends. Ellerbe was gunned down in 2015, and Tonya believes this perceived affiliation – and belief that Bailey was a gang member, too – got him killed.

Tonya Bailey was trying to move her son out of state when he was killed in 2017, shortly after being released from prison.

"My son died because of the gang violence, and it's not because he was a gang banger," Bailey said. "It's because of who he was friends with."

She fears that the videos and social media posts will only continue the violence, especially when the music carries vague threats.

Many of the young men who were friends with her son are paranoid of who may be shot next, especially in a city where surviving until your 18th or 21st birthday is "making it," she said.

"It's sad that you have to walk on the streets in the city of Wilmington and be paranoid," Bailey said. "I tell them, 'Focus on the gun violence and go higher in life. What do you want out of your life? Stop feeding into it.'"

In the music video, as young men twist their hands into Js for Ellerbe, mimic shooting at the camera with their fingers and smoking blunts, they talk about their fallen friends.

“I do this sh*t for Ry and I do this sh*t for Jordan. Can’t let them take my life, I bust my gun and keep it going. Can’t let them take my life, I bust my gun, I had to show them.”

Ryan Schneese's mother, Bethanne, hasn't yet gotten justice for her son's death, but she is hopeful that a new detective at Wilmington Police Department will find his killer.

The 21-year-old was shot twice on March 11 near Taylor and North Pine streets. He died two weeks later, after returning home from the hospital and falling ill.

She's doubtful that any of Ryan's friends will speak up.

"I used to tell him, 'They're no good, Ryan. Something is going to happen to you, and they're going to walk right past you and leave you,'" Schneese said. "But he never said anything about any gangs. He just always told me, because of Jordan, they don't like him."

That beef — and association with Ellerbe and his friends — is likely what got him killed. Schneese said police are looking into a young man connected with the OMB gang in his killing, but no charges have been filed.

Until Ellerbe was killed, Schneese said she didn't worry about her son's safety in Wilmington. He lived in the Hilltop neighborhood with his aunt and quickly befriended Ellerbe, who lived nearby. Prosecutors have described Ellerbe has an "associate" of STK gang members.

Now, she's heartbroken over what she never knew.

"I didn't realize it was that deep," Schneese said of the violence surrounding her son. “It was over nothing.''

“Just senseless crap,” she said.

August 30th would have been Ryan’s 24th birthday. Schneese hopes to find a way to honor her "miracle child,” a young man that survived numerous open heart surgeries, a pacemaker implant, and eventually, a heart transplant at 17.

In many ways, he was never expected to make it. She never imagined losing her son to gunfire.

Schneese struggles to understand how the violence continues, especially when young men end up burying their friends.

"You’re so hurt because you lost your friend,” she said of the retaliatory violence, “but put yourself in another person’s position. Think about the family.”

Ahmed "Akadoo" Burks stood outside Cash Money Mini Market, a group of high school boys surrounding him.

Clad in a gray sweatshirt, black pants, white sneakers and a black backward-facing hat, Burks laughed as the teenagers, some taller than him, dogged on one another. Another member of the Touch Money Gang pleaded guilty Wednesday to one of six murders state prosecutors pinned on the Wilmington street gang back in 2015.

Alexander Fitzgerald, now 21, stood before Delaware Superior Court Judge William Carpenter Jr. in a white jumpsuit Delaware Department of Correction Wednesday afternoon as the judge explained what his guilty plea would mean.

In addition to the second-degree murder of 17-year-old Deshon Sellers in February 2015, Fitzgerald also pleaded guilty to gang participation and possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony. All other charges were dropped as part of the plea agreement.

"Yes, I plead guilty," Fitzgerald told the court after Carpenter clarified that even though the young man had only completed school up to the 10th grade, he still was able to read and understand the agreement laid out before him.

Prosecutors recommended a 20-year prison sentence. Fitzgerald won't be sentenced until the judge reviews a pre-sentencing investigation of him and makes his decision at a hearing slated for Oct. 26.

BACKGROUND: 13 gang members face 91 charges, including murder

Fitzgerald was scheduled to begin a jury trial on July 9 on charges that could have landed him a life sentence in state prison. As of Monday, he had rejected all plea offers, according to court records.

State Prosecutor John Downs told the judge that they planned to call multiple members of the Touch Money Gang who already pleaded guilty as part of their case, in addition to two people who witnessed the shooting and two others whom prosecutors said Fitzgerald told about the fatal shooting.

Other investigators with the Wilmington Police Department who studied the Touch Money Gang likely would have been called, as well, Downs said.

Court records indicated that state prosecutors had a "voluminous amount" of evidence — including FBI reports, cell phone records and crime scene photos — as part of the case against the gang, whose members ranged in age from 15 to 23 at the time of the indictment.

Sellers' mother, Lanita Brooks, sat quietly behind state prosecutors in the courtroom Wednesday as the plea agreement was explained. She has struggled in the years since her son's death to make sense of why someone would kill him.

GRIEF:For these Wilmington-area moms, Mother's Day will never be the same

Many of those details, which likely would have been brought to light during the trial, will now remain unknown to the public.

Prior to Wednesday's court hearing, Brooks said she didn't want to see a plea deal occur in relation to her son's death.

"He should be locked up forever," she said through tears.

But even with the prospect of a trial looming on the horizon, Brooks was anxious. No sentence would adequately bring justice, she said.

"Even though this day is coming, my son isn't coming back," she said. "We still lose."

search_result.title: Delaware teachers taught to recognize gang signs
search_result.text:
Brittany Horn

The News Journal

When it comes to violence among teens, investigators, parents and educators need to look no further than the phones young people are carrying.

That’s the message that gang prevention specialist Ron “Cook” Barrett gave Delaware educators and administrators Monday at the annual East Coast Gang Investigators Association in Rehoboth Beach. The annual conference, coordinated in part by Wilmington Police Sgt. Bill Schmid, stretches the week and focuses on law enforcement, but expanded its first day this year to include those who see students where most of this behavior is beginning.

Barrett, who has been working in gang prevention since 1999 when he worked as a school resource officer in Albany, New York, stressed that despite stereotypes portrayed in pop culture, groups of loosely affiliated teenagers are driving today’s gang culture. The teens use social media to insult and provoke each other, often resulting in gunfire that can be deadly.

The pattern matches a recent indictment of 28 young men, ages 16 to 21, for 109 felony charges including gang participation, assault and other charges in Wilmington.

While the major organizations, like the Bloods and the Crips still exist, Barrett said it’s often the younger crews emulating what they see and hear in music videos and on TV that can be the most dangerous. Wilmington’s indictment explained a growing rivalry between the street gangs Only My Brothers, or OMB, and Shoot to Kill.

STORY: 6 teens added to Wilmington gang indictment; 28 arrested

STORY: Alleged gang member slips out side door of DOC center

“We’re seeing a generation lost,” Barrett said, noting how many young men have been lost in Chicago neighborhoods and across the nation to gang violence. “We can’t keep saying they’re wannabes because, to me, a wannabe is a gonnabe. It’s just a matter of when.”

The information is even more important for educators to face, he said, especially because students are now carrying their frustrations from the streets into school. Because social media can reach anywhere, Barrett said, teachers and educators need to know what to look for and how to stop it when it comes into their purview.

The information – like recognizing gang signs, identifying traditional markings and understanding the lingo – isn’t new to most law enforcement officials working the streets, Schmid said, but getting it in front of teachers is a new step.

“We, as law enforcement, can’t always be the enforcer all the time,” Schmid said, adding that many issues, especially those relating to gangs, may be visible within school walls. “They can educate them and help them work better with their problems while recognizing what’s in front of them.”

“That way, we can let schools remain safe havens,” he said.

The conference will continue through Friday in Rehoboth. About 200 law enforcement officials flocked to the beach town for training and collaboration. That’s the only way to solve the problem, Barrett said – by working together.

“We have gang problems no matter where you go,” he said. “Gangs are alternatives to the [traditional] family. … If there was an answer to this epidemic, I wouldn’t be here.”

search_result.title: For these Wilmington-area moms, Mother's Day will never be the same
search_result.text:
Brittany Horn

The (Wilmington, Del.) News Journal

Twelve days before Mother’s Day 2016, Tamra Bailey's phone lit up with messages and calls.

The news was grim. Her 25-year-old son, Tymeer, had been fatally shot near New Castle.

One year later, the same thing happened to her sister, Sherice Combs, when her son Bryan Brooks was gunned down in Wilmington.

Their sons were killed on April 25, one year apart – victims of Delaware’s gun violence epidemic that largely targets young African American men. The next place these women saw their sons was at the funeral home.

“I know it’s rough for so many women. I just never thought...” Bailey said, trailing off. “I always used to say, 'Oh my God, I could not imagine that feeling.' ”

Now, both sisters live it every day. They share a bond that is not uncommon in a city that has recorded more than 120 homicides in the last five years, where moms grieve the loss of a child or live in constant fear of their child being the next victim.

Dozens of these moms have found each other, gathering to meet in community centers and crowding into rowhome living rooms, the walls dotted with plaques and pictures of children they’ve lost.

They say they are the ones who understand each other’s grief and fear the most, their makeshift therapy groups marked with “mmhmms” and “that’s happened to me, too.”

“I will say to rooms of white people: ‘Do you know anybody who's been murdered? Do you know anybody who's been to prison?’ and they will look at me like I’m crazy,” said David Kennedy, director of the National Network for Safe Communities at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York. “I have never said that to a black friend or black colleagues and not have had essentially everybody respond with, ‘Well yes, of course.”

“They do expect it. It is normal,” he said. “It’s the way community life in these places is and has been as long as anybody can remember.”

In cities like Wilmington, where the population doesn’t top 72,000 residents, everyone knows everyone – and everyone knows someone who has been affected by gun violence. Nationally, homicide remains the leading cause of death for black men ages 15-34, according to 2015 data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the most recent data available.

The chances of a mother knowing her child’s killer – or their parent – isn’t uncommon either. Nearly every mother in Wilmington can tell you who killed their son even if no arrest has been made. They’ve passed them on the street or attended barbecues together.

They may even still sit across the kitchen table from each other, depending on how long the friendship dates back.

“She didn’t get up in the morning and make pancakes and tell (her son) to go kill someone,” said Dawn Mason. She said she has known the mother of her son’s killer for more than 20 years. The death of her 24-year-old son, Keith Mason, in Jan. 2015 remains unsolved.

For these mothers, Mother’s Day is just another reminder of the children they buried, and the pain that may never subside.

“It’s so many mothers that’s going to follow us,” Tamra Bailey said, “that have already ... with the same story.”

Going through it alone

Inside the computer lab at the William “Hicks” Anderson Community Center, there weren't enough tissues to go around.

The faces of young men and the children they left behind stare back from photo collages made in their memory. Their mothers, often the only ones left to champion their justice, wear T-shirts emblazoned with a favorite photo and their child's nickname, accompanied by “R.I.P.”

It’s here, in groups called together by Facebook posts and late-night phone calls, that mothers convene.

“I’m sure everybody in here that’s lost their child or any woman that’s lost their child,” Bailey said. “You might see me smiling but inside, basically I’m dying.”

Nearly all of the women gathered on a recent Saturday can name someone else who has also lost a child. And every one of these mothers gathered in a makeshift circle has yet to see an arrest in their child’s killing.

Yet all of them can describe details about the shootings – who was there, how many times their son was shot, who pulled the trigger – details relayed to them by friends or witnesses at the scene. None of these bystanders want to talk to police, but they’ll readily tell the mothers what and who they saw.

The streets talk, but not to law enforcement – and more murders go unsolved.

“People don't want to deal with the police and they don't expect to get help from the police,” said Kennedy, who has long studied Wilmington and cities like it. “Not only do the cases not get cleared but people who are afraid of somebody, they don't call police either, which is another piece of this cycle of retaliation and trauma.”

More:Delaware shooting victim killed on anniversary of friend's death

Nationally, support groups formothers who lost relatives to violent crime don’t exist in the numbers that there are for parents of children lost to addiction or drunk driving. These mothers are left on their own, often feeling like they are the only one fighting to find their child's killer.

“It is the people closest to the dead and the hurt who are most affected,” Kennedy said. “But it goes on and on and on and on. The community experience of the violence and the fear is just devastating.”

It happens in Fort Myers, Florida. In Rochester, New York. In Detroit, Michigan. And in dozens of cities throughout America where grieving families are not asked what happened to their child, but rather, what was he doing out at that hour and whether he was actually a victim, Kennedy said.

It is in these communities where society often asks families whether their child deserved to be killed.

“When I started grieving, there was not any place for people of color to go to,” said 56-year-old Angela McClary, who started the Fort Myers, Florida-Lee County chapter of Parents of Murdered Children in 2016, two years after her son was killed.

“A lot of people don’t know how to start their grieving and they don’t want their information to get out and they don’t want to get it out into the community in the wrong way.”

In the small city on the Gulf Coast about the same size as Wilmington, homicide numbers broke records earlier this decade, surpassing cities with far deadlier reputations like Compton, California.

Grieving relatives feared not only for their safety but for relationships in the close-knit, historically African-American Fort Myers neighborhoods where many of the murders were concentrated and went unsolved, said McClary.

About 1,400 miles away in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, three mothers who lost sons in a 2003 triple shooting maintain a memorial website in honor of the city’s homicide victims. The group, called Mothers Against Gun Violence, meets monthly to offer counseling and other supports to parents in need.

And in Nashville, Clemmie Greenlee serves as the community’s rock, opening her heart and her home to families affected by the city’s violence. Greenlee lost her 29-year-old son, Roderiquez, to gun violence in 2003; her 18-year-old nephew in a fatal shooting three years ago; and her 18-year-old grandson, who was shot and killed in 2016.

"I had nobody to talk to (after my son's death) with all the pain and hurt and shock I was in," she said. "I vowed to myself in the moments after he died, I would never let another mother go through the pain and shock alone as long as I was living."

'I still need help now'

Inside a home in Wilmington's Riverside community last month, some moms crowded onto the couch with pictures of loved ones clutched in their laps. Others perched on stools, their legs twitching restlessly. A few leaned against the wall or settled on the floor, forming a makeshift circle as dusk fell outside.

A Facebook call by Lanita Brooks drew about 18 people to the Wilmington home. Brooks had only expected two or three others. Though most didn’t know each other well, they recognized faces or last names as families began to share their stories. They were names that had dotted the obituaries in the past months and years, and silently connected them all.

Brooks lost her 17-year-old son, Deshon Sellers, in 2015 when a member of the Touch Money Gang opened fire on him around the corner from their home, according to state prosecutors. The young man charged was indicted with 12 other members of the gang. In total, the group was charged in six Wilmington murders and five shootings, a small chunk of the 91 charges against them.

Three years later, Alexander Fitzgerald, now 21, is set to go to trial this summer. But Brooks fears that justice may never be served.

The years since her son’s death have been nothing short of excruciating. The 40-year-old mother tried to kill herself after her son’s death but failed. Today, she remains on medication to help maintain an appetite, something she said she hasn’t had since her son’s killing.

Each day, Brooks fights to keep her son’s memory alive, both in legacy and in law. She and her sister, Sharita Sewell, have accompanied state Attorney General Matt Denn to Legislative Hall on numerous occasions to help lobby for more restrictive gun laws.

“I still need help now,” she told the gathered group tearfully, urging them to come together to support one another even if other government agencies seem to fail them.

“It’s not fair because yes, Poppy (Deshon Sellers) was the victim but we’re all victims,” she said.

Some mothers – like Jean Cameron, who lost her 31-year-old son, Clifton Thompson Jr. in Feb. 2016, and Beth Ann Schneese, who lost her 21-year-old son, Ryan, in March 2016 – fear closure may never come.

Reginald Waters, the man charged with Thompson’s killing, is scheduled to begin his trial Monday.

Schneese said her son told her who shot him – wounds that led to his death about two weeks later. Police have not made an arrest.

“I don’t have any hope no more,” she said, adding that her son’s death has upended her life. In addition to mental health issues, Schneese finds it nearly impossible to hold down a job in the wake of Ryan’s killing.

More:Growing up under fire: Wilmington, Delaware, leads U.S. in teen shootings

It is for all of these reasons that Brooks wants to unite this tragedy-stricken community. Her personal Facebook page has turned into a page for moms and family members to plan their next move.

Brooks is trying to gather parents on June 2 at Grace United Methodist Church on North Washington Street to create a documentary about their loss.

The goal is to not lose touch with each other.

“We gotta stick together,” Brooks said tearfully, “because it’s the only way we’re gonna stop this.”

'I know all these babies'

When Mother's Day comes, each mom will awaken and face the day without their child – some for the first time.

Jackie Kinard will visit Silverbrook Cemetery in memory of her son, Terrance, who was gunned down the day before Mother’s Day in 2016. Nearly 10 years before, gun violence took her 21-year-old son, Omar. The holiday, she said, will never be the same.

Dawn Mason will hit replay over and over again Sunday just to hear the sounds of her son, Keith, singing Tupac’s “Dear Mama” through her phone speakers. It’s all she has left of her son, who was the city's first murder victim of 2015.

Tondra Mangrum may barbecue, even if her grill master isn’t at his rightful spot. Her son, Jamar Kilgoe, was killed inside the Rose Hill Community Center in February 2015. Last year, on the day after Mother’s Day, her youngest son was left paralyzed from the waist down due to gun violence.

The list will continue to grow, they fear, if more isn’t done to address the root causes of Wilmington’s violence.

Shootings are down this year under the leadership of Wilmington Police Chief Robert Tracy, who pledged to bring a new strategy to the city to respond more quickly to shootings and identify those most likely to become targets.

Because much of this strategy plays out in police investigations, it is hard to say how successful the initiative has been in solving crimes. The department earlier this week pointed to a 63 percent reduction in gun-related homicides and a 61 percent reduction in shootings so far this year.

Those numbers take into account Monday morning’s homicide that claimed the life of 35-year-old Khalif Friend, who was found shot to death in a vehicle.

Both Mayor Mike Purzycki and Tracy were cautiously optimistic about the numbers, especially heading into summer – when crime notoriously spikes with the temperature.

“Neither the chief nor I know whether these improving numbers will continue throughout the year,” Purzycki said in a statement. “But it is encouraging to know that the WPD’s new emphasis on community engagement, intelligence-led policing, directed patrols and instituting the CompStat methodology are producing better results than we have seen in the past few years.”

It’s going to take a lot of work to undo the “horrific, historical prejudice and oppression and current, at best, racism and neglect” of largely black communities that has allowed violence to go unchecked for decades, said Kennedy, who worked with Tracy in the past.

He said while Wilmington is showing progress, the battle to undo the effects of gun violence can be slow and difficult work.

More:Wilmington suspects get younger, but their guns are more powerful

Take the city’s latest homicide, a killing that struck Jackie Kinard as the latest blow in an already difficult week.

Khalif Friend steadfastly brought the Wilmington mother flowers on the anniversary of her son, Terrance’s death. He would again appear on Mother’s Day, bearing gifts her two sons – victims of the city’s killings – couldn’t bring themselves.

Less than two weeks before, Friend stood at the gravesite of Bryan Brooks and Tymeer Bailey, releasing balloons in honor of his cousins.

Now, he’s another young man Kinard says the city stole from them.

“It’s been a living hell,” Kinard said of her experience in Wilmington. “When I go to the cemetery, I don’t visit one son. I visit two.”

And during those visits, Kinard quickly came to find she knew far more people buried in Silverbrook Cemetery.

“Oh my god,” Kinard recalled thinking. “I know all these babies.”

Between her and her husband, Kelly Harrison, they can name about 15 to 20 mothers affected by the city’s gun violence, and another 50 who have lost someone. Harrison’s son, McKinley Harden, was stabbed to death in Wilmington more than a decade ago.

Still, they can’t bring themselves to leave the city they’ve known all their lives. They argue they should not have to, that violence should not be able to run residents from the streets.

Every shooting rocks Kinard's and Harrison’s home. Kinard has a daughter and son, both of whom live in Wilmington, along with grandchildren and extended family and friends.

“You go straight into panic mode,” Kinard said. “Is it my baby? Is it my family?”

This network of grief weaves through Wilmington and some of its suburbs, sliding inside households and leaving in its wake empty seats at dinner tables and photo collages from funerals held too soon. Kinard and mothers like her have too many empty chairs.

Still, they hope. Still, they pray – that other mothers and families will never have to experience their pain, their loss.

Despite all of the ways in which violence has ripped through her family’s lives, Tondra Mangrum knows that nearly every family in Wilmington is “going through something.”

Yet, she believes in forgiveness.

“I got to,” Mangrum said, “because I want to see my son again. And if I don’t forgive, I’m not.”

Follow Brittany Horn on Twitter @brittanyhorn

search_result.title: Brandon Wingo shooter found guilty, faces life sentence
search_result.text:
Diamonte Taylor faces life in prison after being found guilty of first-degree murder in the shooting death of 15-year-old Brandon Wingo.

After deliberating for about two days, the jury on Wednesday returned guilty verdicts on charges of murder, assault, gang participation and aggravated menacing. Taylor had also been charged with shooting another person and threatening two associates of a rival street gang the month he killed Wingo.

Prosecutors said Taylor, 20, shot Wingo as part of a violent war between rival teen groups in the city in May 2016.

"It was insane: the back and forth between rival gangs that spring leading into summer and it had to stop," said Deputy Attorney General Mark Denney.

Taylor was one of three alleged members of the Shoot to Kill gang indicted for several felonies including the death of Wingo, who was gunned down while walking home on Clifford Brown Walk from Howard High School of Technology.

A former STK gang member said Wingo was killed as part of his gang's rivalry with the Only My Brothers gang and was targeted after he posted a message on Facebook disrespecting an STK associate.

While more notorious gangs are bound by a common trade like drug dealing, prosecutors said the rivalry between the two street gangs played out in violent emotion on social media.

"This was not the type of gang that was centered around a business, or an enterprise or even drug dealing," Denney said after the verdict. "It was centered around shooting and Shoot to Kill was a fitting name."

Prosecutors entered into evidence posts threatening violence against OMB members that showed STK members contorting their fingers to upside down Bs, meant as a sign of disrespect for the deceased Wingo.

Prosecutors showed the jury a Facebook post from after the murder that they said Taylor's co-defendant put up suggesting Wingo should have left his book bag at school so "he would have been lighter on his feet."

Students who were walking with Wingo the day he died told the jury they were approached by a man in a black coat who killed Wingo, but prosecutors found it difficult to present witnesses that put Taylor specifically at the scene.

One woman who said she saw Taylor run from the scene contradicted herself numerous times while another student who identified Taylor told the jury she felt pressured by investigators to pin the shooting on him.

Evidence putting Taylor at the scene and planning the murder largely came from Kevon Harris-Dickerson, a former STK member who was indicted alongside Taylor. After the verdict, Deputy Attorney General Matthew Frawley said Harris-Dickerson was an "important" part of the case.

"Someone like that is able to give you information you would not otherwise be able to ascertain unless you are talking to someone who is actually in the gang and can talk about motives, how they facilitated crimes and what their motives were," Frawley said.

Harris-Dickerson told the jury Taylor and Zaahir Smith, 20, the other of the three indicted for the murder, discussed shooting Wingo or any other of STK's rival Only my Brothers gang after Wingo put a post on Facebook disrespecting a dead STK associate.

Harris-Dickerson said the feud between STK and OMB began with the Jan. 2015 death of Jordan Ellerbe, an STK associate who took a bullet to the head when a gunman sprayed shots at him and other friends hanging out on a porch in the city's Hilltop neighborhood.

Prosecutors entered into evidence Facebook posts including pictures of STK members contorting their fingers into Js as a tribute to Ellerbe, whose murder has not been solved.

Harris-Dickerson said he was driving with Taylor when they noticed Wingo walking home. Taylor wanted to shoot from the car but Harris-Dickerson said he exited the car with a black jacket and a 9mm handgun, which he said later became known as the "Wingo dropper."

He said Taylor admitted to shooting Wingo in the head when they met immediately after the shooting. He told the jury Taylor laughed as they drove by Wingo's body on the pavement before police arrived.

Investigators said Taylor sent a message to a friend claiming he had just "bodied" a person shortly after Wingo was killed and Harris-Dickerson said the three fled to North Carolina afterward to avoid police attention.

Denney said the tit-for-tat nature of the rivalry continued later that night when three juveniles were arrested carrying guns at a home they thought Taylor was at. The next night, the home was "shot up," he said.

"The violence was out of control at that time," Denney said. "It was back and forth. A lot of it was based on social media: the taunting, the promotion, the intimidation and it had to stop."

Ben Gifford, one of Taylor's defense attorneys, sought to discredit Harris-Dickerson. He pointed out discrepancies between his testimony and statements to the jury made by other witnesses. After the verdict, he declined comment pending Taylor's sentencing.

During the trial, he noted the former gang member was facing life in prison plus 50 years if guilty of the charges he was indicted for in summer 2016.

He also noted Harris-Dickeson had more than a year to review evidence gathered by investigators and confer with his lawyer regarding the prosecution's theory before striking a deal and giving his statement to police in February.

"Kevon Harris-Dickerson put on a show," Gifford told the jury.

In return for his testimony, many charges against Harris-Dickerson were dropped. He will do eight years in jail outside the state and has agreed never to return to Delaware.

Taylor's first-degree murder conviction carries a mandatory life sentence. He was also convicted on charges in two other crimes in May.

Prosecutors said Taylor was the triggerman who shot a suspected rival gang member in the hip in the presence of two children. Surveillance videos show two men dressed in black approaching the scene on Wilmington's east side.

Harris-Dickerson identified the men as Smith and Taylor and said Taylor shot the victim.

Days after the shooting, Taylor texted a friend that "I just scored on some crazy s*** babe but I don't think he died," prosecutors said. Another message presented by investigators features Taylor referencing "when I hit" the victim.

He was convicted of assault and reckless endangering for the shooting.

Taylor was also convicted of aggravated menacing after two teens said he and Smith stalked them on the Church Street Bridge days after the Wingo shooting.

The two teens told police that they were approached by a car, Smith exited with a gun and one witness said Taylor was pointing at them for Smith to shoot.

A text message prosecutors said was sent on Taylor's cell phone after said the gunman "tired to blow but didn't shoot." Smith was arrested with a .22 handgun later that day.

Taylor was acquitted of a robbery charge as part of the case as well.

Two men testified that Smith robbed them at gunpoint in May 2016 after they gave Smith and Taylor a ride to the gas station. The witnesses said Taylor was inside the car and prosecutors said he aided in the robbery.

Taylor's prints were found on the car but his attorney said prosecutors had not presented enough evidence to show that Taylor was actively involved in the robbery.

Denney said Smith will be tried for that crime as well as first-degree murder as an accomplice in Wingo's death later this year.

"He's next," Denney said.

search_result.title: Saquon Barkley stats today: Eagles RB nears single-game NFL ...
search_result.text:
The Philadelphia Eagles made a big investment when they signed Saquon Barkley to a three-year deal during the 2024 NFL offseason. Thus far, the move has paid off in a big way.

Barkley entered the team's "Sunday Night Football" meeting with the Los Angeles Rams among the league leaders in rushing yards.

He exits it on pace to break Eric Dickerson's decades-long single-season rushing record after enjoying a massive outing in Los Angeles.

Here's what to know about Barkley's personal-best outing against the Rams and the record-breaking pace he is on during his debut season in Philadelphia.

NFL WEEK 12:32 things we learned, including missteps that could cost some contenders

NFL STATS CENTRAL: The latest NFL scores, schedules, odds, stats and more.

Saquon Barkley stats today

Barkley had the most productive game of his NFL career on Sunday night. He logged a career-high 255 rushing yards on 26 carries and added 47 receiving yards on four catches in the 37-20 Eagles win.

Barkley was productive from the jump against the Rams. He repeatedly ripped off solid gains during the first half, averaging 5.6 yards per carry in the first half and keeping Philadelphia's offense on a consistent schedule against Los Angeles' opportunistic defense.

On the first play of the second half, Barkley nearly doubled his first half production. He took the opening carry 70 yards for a score, following great blocking from the right side of his offensive line and Landon Dickerson into space. He wasn't touched en route to the end-zone.

Barkley continued to be an explosive playmaker from there. He logged a 31-yard catch on a third-and-10 that set up a 13-yard Kenneth Gainwell touchdown before punctuating his career-best night with a 72-yard touchdown run to seal the game.

Barkley's personal-best rushing performance came just over a month after he nearly eclipsed it against the New York Giants. In that contest, Barkley opted to bow out of the 28-3 blowout to allow his teammates to get work rather than chase the record.

In the closer 37-20 contest with the Rams, Barkley remained in and managed to clear his record, originally set against Washington in 2019. He also beat his previous career-high of 279 scrimmage yards from that outing, replacing it with his 302-yard total on Sunday night.

Most rushing yards in an NFL game

Barkley's 255 rushing yards were the ninth-most in a single game in NFL history, and the most by an NFL player since Jonathan Taylor's 253-yard outing against the Jacksonville Jaguars in 2021.

Below is a full look at the NFL's single-game rushing leaders:

Adrian Peterson, Minnesota Vikings: 296 yards (2007) Jamal Lewis, Baltimore Ravens: 295 yards (2003) Jerome Harrison, Cleveland Browns: 286 yards (2009) Corey Dillon, Cincinnati Bengals: 278 yards (2000) Walter Payton, Chicago Bears: 275 yards (1977) O.J. Simpson, Buffalo Bills: 273 yards (1976) Shaun Alexander, Seattle Seahawks: 266 yards (2001) Jamaal Charles, Kansas City Chiefs: 259 yards (2010) Saquon Barkley, Philadelphia Eagles: 255 yards (2024) Jonathan Taylor, Indianapolis Colts: 253 yards (2021); DeMarco Murray, Dallas Cowboys: 253 yards (2011)

Saquon Barkley rushing yards 2024

Barkley has accounted for 1,392 rushing yards in 2024. That ranks No. 1 in the NFL, though it's worth noting that the NFL's No. 2 rusher, Derrick Henry, hasn't yet played his Week 12 game.

That said, Barkley has already had his bye while Henry has not. As such, Barkley remains on pace to lead the league in rushing yards during his first season with the Eagles.

NFL single-season rushing record

Eric Dickerson still owns the NFL record for most rushing yards in a single season. He ran for 2,104 yards during the 1984 NFL season.

Only eight NFL players have logged more than 2,000 rushing yards in a single season:

Eric Dickerson, Los Angeles Rams: 2,105 yards (1984) Adrian Peterson, Minnesota Vikings: 2,097 yards (2012) Jamal Lewis, Baltimore Ravens: 2,066 yards (2003) Barry Sanders, Detroit Lions: 2,053 yards (1997) Derrick Henry, Tenenssee Titans: 2,027 yards (2020) Terrell Davis, Denver Broncos: 2,008 yards (1998) Chris Johnson, Tennessee Titans: 2,006 yards (2009) O.J. Simpson, Buffalo Bills: 2,003 yards (1973)

Barkley is currently on pace to record 2,151 rushing yards during the 2024 NFL season. That would allow him to overtake Dickerson and break the NFL record.

Barkley doesn't have much room for error, but if he can stay healthy, he might have a chance to make NFL history in his first year with the Eagles — whether it's by breaking the NFL rushing record or challenging for 2,000 yards on the ground.

search_result.title: 10 things to know about Philadelphia Eagles Saquon Barkley
search_result.text:
Philadelphia Eagles running back Saquon Barkley is having an MVP-caliber season and could set the NFL single-season rushing record.

While Eagles fans wear his jersey or T-shirts with him doing a backward hurdle over a Jacksonville player, what do we know about Saquon? Here's a quick look at 10 popular questions asked about the Eagles' star.

How old is Saquon Barkley?

Barkley is 27. He was born on Feb. 9, 1997, in The Bronx in New York.

Where did Saquon Barkley go to school?

Barkley attended Whitehall High School in Whitehall Township, Pennsylvania. He then attended Penn State.

All things Eagles: Latest Philadelphia Eagles news, schedule, roster, stats, injury updates and more.

Running for the record:Is Saquon Barkley on pace to break the NFL single-season rushing record? Here's a look

What is Saquon Barkley famous for?

He is an elite running back in the National Football League. He was the 2018 NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year and he's been to the Pro Bowl twice.

How high can Saquon Barkley jump?

At the NFL Combine in 2018, Barkley had an unofficial 41-inch vertical leap. While he may or may not be able to clear that height now, he did clear a Jacksonville Jaguars defender while leaping backward, so that's pretty good.

How many rings does Saquon Barkley have?

None yet, but his prospects this season with the Eagles are looking pretty good. The Eagles are tied with the Buffalo Bills with the third-best odds to win the Super Bowl.

Is Saquon Barkley related to Iran Barkley?

The former boxer is the great-uncle of Saquon Barkley.

Is Saquon Barkley related to Charles Barkley?

The current Philly football star isn't related to the former Philly basketball star.

Is Saquon Barkley married?

According to msn.com, Barkley is in a relationship with Anna Congdon and the couple has two children together – Jada Clare and Saquon Jr.

Has Saquon Barkley ever played quarterback in the NFL?

Yes, during the fourth quarter during a 2022 game against the Chicago Bears. Barkley was forced into the role after Daniel Jones and Tyrod Taylor both were injured. Barkley moved into the quarterback and Joes entered the game as a wide receiver. With Barkley at quarterback, the Giants gained some yards on a run and eventually kicked a field goal for the final point in a 20-12 victory.

Who is better, Saquon Barkley or Christian McCaffrey?

While both are elite running backs, Barkley is pursuing the NFL single-season rushing record. McCaffrey, on the other hand, has battled injuries all season and is out for the year after injuring his knee on Dec. 1 against the Buffalo Bills. So, for this year, Saquon is better.

search_result.title: Eagles Saquon Barkley's role in AJ Brown, Jalen Hurts passing issues
search_result.text:
PHILADELPHIA − What often gets lost in this entire A.J. Brown-fueled Eagles' passing game debate is the player at the heart of it: running back Saquon Barkley.

It's no secret that the Eagles aren't passing the ball as much because of Barkley, who's on pace to break the NFL's single-season rushing record, set by Eric Dickerson with 2,105 yards rushing in 1984.

There's no bitterness about that. Barkley averages 125 yards rushing per game. He'll break Dickerson's record if he averages 121 yards per game over the Eagles' final four games, beginning Sunday against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Conversely, Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts is averaging just 21 pass attempts per game during the Eagles' nine-game winning streak. He threw for just 108 yards last Sunday in the Eagles' 22-16 win over the Carolina Panthers, one week after Hurts threw for 118 yards in the Eagles' 24-19 win over the Baltimore Ravens.

BLAMING BG:Eagles have scapegoat for Jalen Hurts, A.J. Brown friction, passing woes. Can they fix it?

All things Eagles: Latest Philadelphia Eagles news, schedule, roster, stats, injury updates and more.

PLAYOFF STAKES:Eagles can clinch more than NFC East title with win and some help. No, not the No. 1 seed

After the win over the Panthers, Brown was asked what needs to improve.

"Passing," he said.

That began three days of controversy, fueled in part by defensive end Brandon Graham's comments on SportsRadio 94 WIP on Monday implying that Hurts' and Brown's relationship is strained. Graham walked that back the next day, followed the next day by both Brown and Hurts saying they're fine and that they're working to improve the passing game.

On Thursday, Barkley weighed in.

"It's not like it's not a problem for us," Barkley said. "Obviously, we have to answer the questions ... But we're not sitting at lunch table talking about, 'Oh, we need to throw the ball more.'

"To be honest, you guys in the media are the ones kind of creating that narrative. Our focus is winning football games. And we're 11-2 right now. We got nine wins in a row. We know there's a lot we can continue to improve on because of the things we want to accomplish, and we got to keep on doing it."

Barkley has no doubt that the Eagles can win with the passing game if an opponent, such as the Steelers, were to shut Barkley down. And that's possible, considering the Steelers have the fourth-ranked rushing defense in the NFL, allowing just 91.5 yards per game.

"Yeah, 100% confidence," Barkley said about the passing game. "We have A.J. Brown. We have DeVonta Smith. We have Jalen Hurts ... If we’re throwing for 350 yards and we’re not rushing that great, would people still have the same conversations?

"It’s not real. What matters is winning football games. Yes, we want to do better. We know the kind of talent that we have."

Perhaps the Eagles' drama this week was partially intended to get the Steelers thinking about the Eagles' passing game more, thereby taking some of their attention from Barkley. Or if the Steelers focus their attention on Barkley, then the Eagles will have to take advantage of the pass game.

Either way, both Brown and Hurts admitted that Barkley has changed the Eagles' offense − for the better.

"When (a reporter) asked the question of what the offense can do better, obviously it’s not about running the ball," Brown said. "(Barkley) is about to win MVP. Like, literally, what’s the other thing we do on offense? We have to pass the ball.

"That’s why I was bringing the awareness to everybody’s attention. This is something we can focus on. We know we can run the ball. Saquon is doing a great job. We’re not against running the ball. We love Saquon. Ask him what I tell him … during the game. Like, ‘Do your job,’ in the game."

Barkley confirmed that Thursday, but he also knows that Brown can change a game too. It was something Barkley said he used to talk about with Daniel Jones during the past few years when he and Jones were teammates on the Giants.

"He's a freak of nature," Barkley said of Brown. "He weighs the same as me. He's bigger than me and he can move like me. I just can't run routes like him. The most precious thing about AJ, to me, is every time the ball (comes to him), you got guys that catch the ball, (but) he catches the ball the ball does not move ...

"He's a heck of a player. A Hall of Fame caliber player and excited having him on my team."

The feeling is mutual for Brown toward Barkley. Now, it's up to the Steelers to figure out which one to stop. That, no doubt, will start with the Steelers trying to stop Barkley. And through all of the passing game controversy this week, the Eagles will still have to run the ball.

Barkley knows it, Hurts knows it, and Brown and Smith know it. So do the Steelers."We gotta make (the Steelers) stop it," Barkley said about the running game. "And if they can’t, they can’t. And if they happen to do it, we’re more than capable of being able to throw the ball and win football games.

"Whether we have 10 passing yards and 10 rushing yards, five picks, three fumbles, and we win the game 3-0 because the special teams played great and the defense played great, at the end of the day, we won the football game."

To Barkley, that's all that matters.

Eagles rule out punt returner Britain Covey

WR/PR Britain Covey was ruled out of the game Sunday with a neck injury, meaning that CB Cooper DeJean will be the main punt returner. Covey missed last week's game with the same injury, which he suffered in the Dec. 1 game against the Ravens. Covey was limited in practice Wednesday, but practiced fully Thursday and Friday.

Everyone else is eligible to play Sunday, including WR Johnny Wilson, who didn't practice Friday because of an illness.

For the Steelers, WR George Pickens, who leads the team with 850 yards, was ruled out with a hamstring injury.

search_result.title: Saquon Barkley for NFL MVP? Eagles RB's case not as good as you ...
search_result.text:
There's no denying Saquon Barkley’s greatness.

There’s no denying he salvaged his career by signing with the Philadelphia Eagles this year – or, said differently, by escaping the New York (Little?) Giants. There’s no denying we’re all being treated to appointment football now that he’s been granted deserved prime-time stages – starting with his Eagles debut in South America (of all places) in Week 1 to his pair of marquee performances over the past 12 days – worthy of transcendent abilities that were compared to the (nearly) incomparable Barry Sanders’ when Barkley came out of Penn State in 2018.

But should he be the NFL MVP in 2024? Gotta deny him that one.

It’s perfectly understandable to link him to the league’s premier award for football excellence – though no running back has won it since 2012, Adrian Peterson the only runner so honored in the past 18 years. Yet to watch Barkley follow up his scintillating Week 11 showing, when he broke the Washington Commanders by incinerating their defense multiple times in the fourth quarter, to his tour de force Sunday night – a career-best (and club record) 255 rushing yards and more than 300 overall in front of a national audience is the stuff of legends (and bronze busts) – begets debates, shifting betting odds and plays into our (temporary) obsession with the shiny object du jour.

Even Los Angeles Rams head coach Sean McVay fueled the discussion following his team's 37-20 defeat.

NFL STATS CENTRAL: The latest NFL scores, schedules, odds, stats and more.

“He's as good as there is as a slash runner, to be able to work edges and then be able to erase angles and be able to finish,” he said after watching Barkley render LA’s late-game defensive gambles oh so pointless.

“That’s why he had the production that he had, and that's why he’s had arguably an MVP-type of season so far.”

Eagles coach Nick Sirianni said of No. 26: “He's got everything you look for in a back. He's been awesome, and he was awesome tonight.”

Maybe, at some point, Barkley's candidacy becomes undeniable. With the benefit of the 17-game regular season, he's on pace to do what Peterson couldn't quite manage 12 years ago – namely, break Hall of Famer Eric Dickerson's single-season rushing record of 2,105 yards, set over 16 games in 1984. Barkley is on pace for 2,151, and the Eagles (9-2) might need him for all 17 games in a bid to overtake the Detroit Lions (10-1) in the race for home-field advantage and a first-round bye in the NFC side of the playoffs.

However I’ve already taken my deep breath since watching Barkley as Hollywood's leading man for a night.

Again, the guy is awesome. The production, reliability, the humble attitude, breakaway speed, ankle-breaking cuts, the reverse hurdle – it’s precisely the type of package we crave in our sports stars. And it sure feels like Barkley has made the Eagles better.

But they’ve also made him better. Waaaaaay better.

Philadelphia is riding a seven-game winning streak and trails only the Lions in the NFC. Conversely, over the past three seasons, this is the Eagles’ worst 11-game start (they were 10-1 in both 2022 and 2023, when Barkley was still toiling in Gotham).

All NFL news on and off the field. Sign up for USA TODAY's 4th and Monday newsletter.

All due respect to Shady McCoy, Brian Westbrook, Wilbert Montgomery and others, Barkley is probably the best back the City of Brotherly Love has called its own since Hall of Famer Steve Van Buren delivered the first two of the franchise’s four titles three-quarters of a century ago. (And all due respect to Van Buren – he scored the only points in a blizzard in the 1948 title game and ran over the Rams for 196 yards in the ’49 championship round, LA apparently a historical feeding ground for Philly backs – but I’d take Barkley.)

Yet let’s remember that the true MVP(s) of the Eagles are almost certainly the five men doing the primary blocking for Barkley, symphonic mauling conducted by legendary offensive line coach Jeff Stoutland. This was a unit that paved the way for Miles Sanders, Barkley's backup with the Nittany Lions, to rush for 1,269 yards in 2022, after which he signed a hefty contract with the Carolina Panthers … and hasn’t been heard from since. This was a group that helped D’Andre Swift craft his only 1,000-yard season in the NFL last year before he joined the Chicago Bears. This is a quintet known for giving rise to the notorious “tush push” – the Philly frontal assault that produces first downs and touchdowns in short-yardage situations practically without fail.

Even following the retirement of iconic center Jason Kelce – after a 2023 campaign that ultimately disintegrated with something akin to a locker room mutiny as Sirianni knee-capped his staff on the fly – Stoutland somehow seems to have made the front five better. Cam Jurgens has capably replaced Kelce. Following Barkley from New York, Mekhi Becton – a first-round washout as the Jets' left tackle – has reinvented himself by taking over the right guard spot vacated by Jurgens and, along with Jordan Mailata, gives Barkley a pair of 360-pounders to run behind. Per the NFL analytics website PFF, Mailata is the league’s preeminent left tackle. Left guard Landon Dickerson is likely headed to his third straight Pro Bowl, and right tackle Lane Johnson might be a first-ballot Hall of Famer whenever he’s done.

Now it’s Barkley, averaging nearly 50 rushing yards more per game than he did during his time with the Giants, who is the beneficiary of this steak-and-cheese grinder that routinely pulverizes opponents into submission.

I was able to witness the formula personally as the Eagles relentlessly pummeled the Commanders. Barkley was steady, if fairly unspectacular most of that night at Lincoln Financial Field – until the dam broke and he ran for a pair of touchdowns covering 62 aggregate yards in a 20-second span in the game’s final five minutes. He wound up with 198 yards from scrimmage.

Chicken? Egg? Hammer? Scythe? Line? Barkley?

“We’ve found a rhythm offensively,” Johnson told me when I asked about their approach and success.

“We love the big, explosive plays. We love handing the ball to Saquon and wearing teams down physically up front. When you can do that, it opens up the pass game, weakens the pass rush when you attack the guys the way that we do. So, complementary football.”

And Barkley is a complementary piece here. That’s not to shade him one iota of the credit he's due, but …

▶ For some reason, quarterback Jalen Hurts still does most of the short-area dirty work, eight of his 11 team-leading TD runs from 1 yard. (Barkley’s TD runs average 31 yards – amazing, including two from 70+ against the Rams – but he hasn’t taken it in from the 1-yard line yet.)

▶ Call it a quirky stat if you like, but the Eagles are 8-0 when Pro Bowl wideout A.J. Brown is available yet 1-2 without him. And Barkley dropped a very catchable pass in Week 2 against the Atlanta Falcons that he himself cited as the reason Philadelphia lost.

▶ A defense teeming with blossoming stars – one that fell apart and maybe even quit in 2023 following the departure of coordinator Jonathan Gannon for the Arizona Cardinals’ top job – is now ranked No. 1 overall with grizzled assistant Vic Fangio calling the shots.

▶ Even Sirianni seems to have gotten out of his own way sufficiently enough that his job status is no longer a weekly discussion point. And say what you want about the polarizing HC, but he does have a highly enviable 43-19 regular-season record and is on the way to his fourth playoff appearance in four seasons – most of that success obviously predating 2024.

Barkley is a superstar, a unicorn at his position, probably an eventual Hall of Famer. He’s an eminently valuable player for the Eagles.

He’s also a tailback playing for a team that might have been one questionable holding call away from beating the Kansas City Chiefs in Super Bowl 57 less than two years ago … without him.

With most profuse apologies to Mr. Barkley, the Buffalo Bills’ Josh Allen, Baltimore Ravens’ Lamar Jackson and maybe even Detroit’s Jared Goff should probably rest rather easy – none of those teams likely to survive without their respective quarterbacks, whereas the Eagles have already proven to be championship-caliber pre-Barkley. In a quarterback-driven league that tends to appropriately reward that all-important position, one of them probably will – and should – be the 2024 MVP.

Sorry, Saquon.

***

Follow USA TODAY Sports' Nate Davis on X, formerly Twitter, @ByNateDavis.
